awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education in the many-body physics of strongly correlated quantum materials. The textbook description of electrons in solids assumes essentially free electrons, moving throughout the solid independently of what all other electrons are doing. Research in the recent past has shown that this description fails in a wide variety of materials, in which electrons in the solid are strongly correlated with each other. In these quantum materials, strong correlations can produce unusual states of matter, and lead to phase transitions between them. These are the quantum analogues of familiar phase transitions such as ice melting into water, or water boiling into vapor. The PI will develop theoretical methods to study the collective behavior of electrons near such phase transitions to understand how novel types of superconductivity can be generated, and to explore how these states evolve under the influence of external electromagnetic fields.

Through the project, the PI will bring about understanding about quantum materials in general, which is a central element of quantum science and technology that has recently emerged as a top national priority. The PI intends to collaborate with leading experimental groups worldwide in this area, thereby creating educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students involved in the PI's research program. The advanced theoretical training will help students prepare for future careers in academia or industry.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education in the physics of strongly correlated quantum materials. Strong correlations can yield novel phases and unusual excitations. In metallic systems, an outstanding challenge is to understand how the correlations generate physics beyond the Fermi-liquid theory. The proposed research will address this open problem, primarily by using systems with both itinerant electrons and localized moments as a prototype setting. The research will develop and apply controlled theoretical methods to study well-defined microscopic and field-theory models. 

The research aims to gain new insights that are broadly relevant to the physics of strongly correlated electrons. The PI will pursue four specific research directions: First, the PI will analyze heavy-fermion quantum criticality, with a focus on Kondo lattice systems that contain entwined degrees of freedom. Second, the PI plans to initiate theoretical studies on the novel phases that emerge near quantum critical points, including pairing state of multiorbital superconductivity that is driven by quantum criticality. Third, the PI will explore non-Fermi-liquid physics in heavy-fermion systems potentially hosting Kondo-driven Weyl nodes, thereby elucidating quantum criticality in a new setting. Fourth, the PI will investigate real-time dynamics under driven conditions as a means of probing quantum criticality. Through concrete model studies, this research direction aims to shed light on the coherence and dynamics of strongly coupled quantum systems out of equilibrium.

Through the project, the PI will bring about understanding about quantum materials in general, which is a central element of quantum science and technology that has recently emerged as a top national priority. The PI intends to collaborate with leading experimental groups worldwide in this area, thereby creating educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students involved in the PI's research program. The advanced theoretical training will help students prepare for future careers in academia or industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supports research on non-Fermi liquid metals, with a particular focus on f-electron based Kondo systems. The specific objectives of the research were a) to develop our recently advanced notion of Weyl-Kondo semimetals; b) to realize new regimes of the global phase diagram for heavy fermion metals; c) to elucidate the singular hybridization-inducedcharge dynamics of the Kondo destruction quantum criticality; d) to explore quantum criticality and emergent phases in low dimensional systems; e) to develop theoretical methodology; f) to articulate a broad perspective in order to set new directions of this exciting field.

In a), we worked out the distribution of Berry curvature near the Fermi energy, finding it to be highly enhanced due to the Kondo-driven pinning of the Weyl nodes to the Fermi energy. This leads to a large spontaneous Hall effect, which has been experimentally observed. This result is central in exploring the signatures of the Weyl-Kondo semimetals.

 

In b), we worked with experimentalists to realize the experimental support for the theoretically proposed global phase diagram. We showed that the kagome metal CePdAl has non-Fermi liquid behavior over an extended range of parameters, which is consistent with a phase expected from our previously advanced global phase diagram that is paramagnetic but features a destruction of Kondo effect and thus small Fermi surface.

 

In c),  we made advances that were enabled by a new continuous-time quantum Monte Carlo method we developed. We theoretically found singular charge response even though the quantum critical point is antiferromagnetic in nature and, concurrently, discovered the effect by showing omega/T scaling in the terahertz optical conductivity in the canonical quantum critical heavy fermion metal YbRh2Si2.

 

In d), we studied two-dimensional models for spin liquid ground states. We show how von Neumann entanglement entropy can be used to reveal and characterize a Fermi surface of spinon excitations.

 

In e), we introduced a continuous time-quantum Monte Carlo (CT-QMC) algorithm to study quantum phase transitions of the Bose-Fermi Anderson Model with SU(2) Symmetry and its cluster generalizations. A key element is a triple expansion in couplings that involve a spin flip.

In f), we summarized the status of an aspect of quantum critical heavy fermions, “Heavy-electron quantum criticality and single-particle spectroscopy”, in a colloquium article in Reviews of Modern Physics. In addition, we summarized the status of “Quantum phases driven by strong correlations'' in an invited review for Nature Reviews Physics and a more general version “The many faces (phases) of strong correlations'' in a featured article in Europhysics News (EPN), the magazine of the European Physical Society that reaches 130,000 members.

Altogether, these research led to sixteen refereed publications, including two in Science family journals, two in Nature family journals, two in Physical Review Letters, two in PNAS, one in Reviews of Modern Physics, as well as many invited talks.

This grant has been instrumental in the development of new scientific talents. It supported the education and research of 2 postdoctoral fellows and 4 graduate students at Rice University. It made possible extensive collaborations with a number of leading theoretical and experimental groups, especially those from Europe.  The collaborations provide an enriched intellectual environment that fostered the development of broader perspectives in the engaged graduate students and postdoctoral fellows along with others at the Rice Center for Quantum Materials. Finally, during the covid-pandemic, I instigated a prolonged, twice-per-week, group meetings which not only allowed in-depth discussions of the research supported by this NSF grant but also contributed to sustaining, through the course of the pandemic, a community that was highly valued by all members of my research group.
